Graphical abstract ZIF-derived carbons (ZDCs) represent a novel category of non-precious metal catalysts (NPMCs) for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). Nevertheless, establishing the correlation between their structure and performance is challenging due to their diverse structural properties and ill-defined active site moieties. Here we investigate the effect of ZIF-67 derived carbon’s particle size and corresponding distribution of assorted nitrogen functionalities on the ORR. Our findings reveal a substantial increase in ORR activity with decreasing ZDC particle size, while the exact influence of nitrogen functionalities remains uncertain. Most importantly, the present work unveils a correlation between the ORR activity and the site density (SD) of Co-Nx within the ZDC materials, which can be attributed to the concurrently increasing SD and accessibility of Co-Nx on the ZDC particles with small sizes. The present work provides novel insights into the optimization of ZDCs as high-performance NPMCs for ORR in alkaline electrolytes. Keywords Oxygen reduction reaction Zeolitic imidazolate frameworks Non-precious metal catalysts Nitrite stripping Active site density Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The electrochemical oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) plays a critical role in various clean energy storage/conversion devices including low temperature fuel cells and metal-air batteries [1–5]. However, the ORR process suffers from slow kinetics and has a high overpotential due to the limited efficiency of electrocatalysts, which significantly impacts the overall efficiency of these devices [6–8]. The current best-performing ORR catalysts are mainly made from platinum group metals (PGMs), but their scarcity and high cost have made the widespread commercial use of these devices prohibitive [9–11]. In view of this, growing efforts have been devoted to the development of cost-effective non-precious metal catalysts (NPMCs) toward the ORR [12–15]. Different from PGM-based catalysts, whose structural parameters such as particle sizes, morphology/exposed facets, and surface compositions can be precisely engineered [16–18], NPMCs are typically prepared via high temperature pyrolysis of the compounds or mixtures containing nitrogen and carbon sources with/without transition metals (e.g., Fe, Co, Mn) [14,19] and thus may not offer the same degree of controllability. During the pyrolysis process, the precursors for NPMCs would undergo substantial structure changes due to the severe thermolysis of organic components which is usually accompanied by uncontrolled agglomeration of carbon or metal phases [20–23], making the rational control of the structural parameters of NPMCs a non-trivial task. In recent years, metal organic frameworks (MOFs), which are characteristic of well-defined nanoporous lattice constructed by organic linkers with coordinated metal nodes, emerge as promising precursors for the synthesis of NPMCs [24–27]. Due to the large structural and chemical diversity, MOFs can be facilely functionalized with various metals and/or heteroatoms, which can then be in situ converted to metal and/or heteroatom doped porous carbon materials by pyrolysis [28–35]. The as-prepared MOF derived carbons can inherit the structural properties of MOFs such as particle sizes and shapes, which opens up the exciting possibility of producing NPMCs via a rational “crystal engineering” approach [24,25]. Among various MOFs, zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) have attracted extensive attention due to the facile size-/shape-controlled synthesis of ZIF nanocrystals under mild conditions [35–39]. ZIF-8 and its analogous ZIF-67 represent the most studied ZIF materials, which feature a unique rhombic dodecahedron particle shape and open porous sodalite structure consisting of tetrahedral clusters of M−N4 (M = Zn, Co) linked by 2-methyl imidazolate (CH3C3H2N2) ligands [40]. The ZIF derived carbons (denoted as ZDCs) can not only retain the 3D open porous structure and the high specific surface area of the ZIF precursor, but also render abundant nitrogen functionalities that are potentially active for O2 adsorption/activation during the ORR [41,42]. Therefore, extensive efforts have been made to innovate the ZDC nanostructures in the development of high performance NPMCs, as reflected by the exponentially growing number of various ZDC nanostructures being explored. The pioneering work dates back to 2011, when Liu et al. made the first attempt to use a cobalt based ZIF as a precursor for synthesizing Co-N-C catalysts toward the ORR [43]. At the same time, Dodelet et al. also reported that ZIF-8 can serve as a porous host for phenanthroline and ferrous acetate, which can be converted to an active ORR catalyst via pyrolysis [44]. Thereafter, a number of M−N−C catalysts derived from ZIF precursors have been reported, primarily driven by the feasibility of facile structural modulation of the ZIF precursors. In a typical example, by tuning the size of ZIF-67 crystals during the synthesis through increasing the molar ratio of methylimidazole to cobalt nitrate, Cui et al. successfully synthesized ZDC particles with average sizes ranging from 300 nm to 3.2 µm [45]. These previous reports mainly focus on the structural engineering of the MOF crystals including their topology, morphology, sizes, and metal centers [31,33,36–38,42,45–47], which play a pivotal role in determining the electrocatalytic performance of the resultant ZDC materials. Despite the feasibility of modulating the structures of ZIF precursors, it should be noted that the derived carbon-based catalysts in many cases show great variation in their electrocatalytic performance even after similar pyrolysis treatment [48]. This divergence can largely be attributed to the uncertain distribution of N- and/or metal-containing entities that potentially act as active sites toward the ORR. For instance, tetra nitrogen-coordinated metal complexes (M−N4) are widely regarded as the most active site toward the ORR in NPMCs [23,26,49]. However, recent findings by Bai et al. on copper ion-exchanged ZIF-8 derived carbons challenged this notion, demonstrating that nitrogen-coordinated copper complexes with lower coordination numbers (Cu-N3) emerge as the primary active sites for ORR [50]. Moreover, Zhao et al. proposed recently based on DFT calculations that the ORR activity of Fe-N4C structure would decrease with the number of coordinating nitrogen atoms. They further postulated that the presence of axially coadsorbed oxygenated species within the Fe-N4C structure(*O-Fe-N4C) was the source of their enhanced ORR activity in alkaline electrolytes [51]. There are also reports suggesting that the ORR activity of NMPCs might stem from the synergistic interplay between metal single atoms, embodied as M−Nx moieties, and metal nanoparticles/nanoclusters [52,53]. Thus, there is a great urgency to establish a robust structure-performance relationship for NPMCs materials toward the ORR. In the present study, we selected ZIF-67 as a prototype precursor to investigate the influence of carbon particle size on the distribution of various nitrogen functionalities and Co-Nx species, as well as their correlation with the ORR activity. Firstly, we synthesized a set of ZIF-67 nanocrystals with average particle sizes ranging from 300 nm to 1.8 µm, followed by pyrolysis and acid leaching to produce ZDC materials with well-defined particle sizes and shapes. Our results reveal that the particle size has little impact on the textural structure of ZDCs, but has a profound effect on their ORR activity in alkaline electrolytes. Specifically, both kinetic current density and diffusion limiting current density increase with the decreasing ZDC particle size. To gain more insights into this size effect, we quantify the site density (SD) of Co-Nx within ZDC using the emerging nitrite adsorption/stripping method. A distinct dependence of the ORR activity on the SD is observed. This is largely due to a combined factor of greater abundance and higher accessibility of active sites within the smaller ZDC particles. The present work clearly suggests that the Co-Nx species plays a decisive role in determining the ORR activity of ZDCs in alkaline electrolytes. The simultaneous increase of both the availability and accessibility of actives sites is the key for the high-performing NPMCs toward the ORR. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials and chemicals 2-Methylimidazole (C4H6N2, 98 %), cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O, 99 %), sodium nitrite (NaNO2, 99 %), and Nafion 117 solution (5 wt%) were purchased from Aladdin Chemistry Co., Ltd. Ethanol (EtOH), methanol (MeOH, 99.7 %) and glacial acetic acid (CH3COOH, 99.5 %) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. All the chemicals and reagents used in this study were in analytical grade and used without further purification. Ultrapure water with a resistivity of 18.2 MΩ·cm (@25 °C) from HHitech water purification system was used in all experiments. 2.2 Sample preparation Synthesis of ZIF-67 samples: In a typical synthesis of ZIF-67 sample with an average particle size of 300 nm, 0.6568 g of 2-methylimidazole was dissolved in 40 ml of methanol and then rapidly poured into 40 ml of a methanol solution containing 0.5821 g of dissolved Co(NO3)2·6H2O, followed by stirring for 10 s and keeping at room temperature overnight. The precipitate obtained by centrifugation was washed more than three times with methanol and finally dried under vacuum for 12 h at 80 °C to give purple solids. The particle sizes of ZIF-67 were regulated by varying the concentrations of 2-methylimidazole and Co(NO3)2·6H2O in the methanol solution while maintaining a constant molar ratio of 4:1 between them. Specifically, ZIF-67 with average sizes of 1.8 μm, 1.1 μm, 800 nm, 600 nm, and 300 nm were prepared by decreasing the concentration of 2-methylimidazole from 24 to 20, 16, 12, 8 mM, respectively. Synthesis of ZDC samples: The as-synthesized ZIF-67 particles were placed in a ceramic crucible and transferred to a horizontal tube furnace. The sample was first dried at 120 °C for 1 h and then heated up to 800 °C under flowing N2 atmosphere for 2 h. After cooling, the sample was treated with 0.5 M H2SO4 solution at 80 °C for 12 h. The solid was then collected by centrifugation, intensively washed with ultrapure water and then vacuum-dried at 80 °C overnight. The prepared samples are designated as ZDC-d, where d ranges from 1 to 5. Each value of d corresponds to a different ZDC sample derived from ZIF-67 particles with an average size ranging from 1.8 µm to 300 nm. 2.3 Structural analysis Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were collected on a BRUKER D2 PHASER X-ray diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54056 Å). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) measurements were performed on a Zeiss GeminiSEM 500 at an accelerating voltage of 5 kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were obtained using a Hitachi H7650 system with an accelerating voltage of 100 kV. High-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) elemental mapping measurements were carried out on a JEM-F200 (JEOL) equipped with an EDAX APOLLO XL X-ray detector. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were recorded on a surface area and pore size analyzer (BSD-PM2, Beishide Instrument). The surface area and pore size distribution were determined using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and the Barrett − Joyner − Halenda (BJH) methods, respectively. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a thermogravimeter (STA449F5, Netzsch) under air atmosphere. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on Thermo Scientific Nexsa XPS spectrometer using monochromatized Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV). The binding energies (BEs) were calibrated against the adventitious C 1 s peak at 284.8 eV. Raman spectrum was carried out on a XploRA PLUS Confocal Raman Microscope (Horiba Scientific). Co K-edge extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) measurements were performed at BL14W1 station in Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF), using a double-crystal Si (111) monochromator. The storage ring of SSRF was operated at 3.5 GeV with the current of 300 mA. Data were acquired in fluorescence excitation mode using a Lytle detector at room temperature. The EXAFS data were background subtracted, normalized, and Fourier transformed by standard procedures within the ATHENA program. Morlet wavelet transform of EXAFS data was processed by hamaFortran program. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements Electrochemical measurements were performed on a CHI760E electrochemical workstation using a conventional three-electrode configuration. The catalyst-coated rotating disk electrode (RDE, 5 mm in diameter, Ivium) and rotating ring-disk electrode (RRDE, 4 mm in disk diameter, 1 mm in ring diameter, 0.5 mm in disk-ring spacing, Ivium) were used as working electrode, with a Hg/HgO electrode and graphite rod as reference and counter electrodes, respectively. All electrode potentials were calibrated against the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE). The catalyst ink was prepared by dispersing 5 mg of catalyst in a mixed solvent containing 495 μl of deionized water, 495 μl of ethanol, and 10 μl of Nafion (5 wt%), followed by a sonication treatment for 30 min. To prepare the working electrode, a calibrated amount of catalysts ink was drop-casted onto RDE or RRDE. The catalyst loading on the RDE was optimized at 0.2 mg cm−2 as a trade-off between ensuring good catalyst layer quality and achieving a thin catalyst layer thickness to minimize mass transport losses within the catalyst layer. To determine the electrochemically accessible surface area (EASA) of various ZDC materials, cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves were recorded at different scan rates (5 – 200 mV s−1) in a N2-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte solution. The EASA can then be determined by plotting the double layer charging current against the scan rates according to the following equations [5]: (1) E A SA = C dl C s (2) C dl = Q E = dQ / d t dE / d t = i r where Cdl is the double layer capacitance derived from the slope of double layer charging current-scan rate plots; Cs is the areal specific capacitance corresponding to a flat standard electrode (∼40 μF cm−2); Q is the quantity of charge; E is the potential; i is the current and r is the scan rate. The ORR performance of ZDC catalyst was evaluated using the thin-film RDE technique. The ORR polarization curves were recorded with a scan rate of 10 mV s−1 in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte at an RDE/RRDE rotation rate of 1600 rpm. The iR-drop effect was compensated by measuring the solution resistance between working and reference electrodes via electrochemical impedance spectroscopy analysis (10 kHz, 5 mV). The mass transfer corrected kinetic current (JK ) of the ORR was determined using the Koutecky-Levich (K-L) equation [54–56]: (3) 1 J = 1 J L + 1 J K = 1 B ω 1 / 2 + 1 J K (4) B = 0.62 n F D 0 2 / 3 ν - 1 / 6 C 0 where J, and JL are the measured current density and limiting diffusion current density, respectively. ω is the angular velocity of the disk in rad s−1; n is the electron transfer number; F is the Faraday constant (96485C mol−1); D0 is the oxygen diffusion coefficient (1.93 × 10-5 cm2 s−1); C0 is the volume concentration of oxygen (1.2 × 10-6 mol cm−3), and ν is the kinetic viscosity of the electrolyte (0.01 cm2 s−1). At least three electrochemical experimental data sets were collected to generate the error bars, which were defined as the standard deviations for each measurement. RRDE tests were performed on a CHI760E bipotentiostat, and the disc current (Id ) and ring current (Ir ) were recorded independently. The potential of the Pt ring was set to 1.3 V (vs. RHE) during the measurement. The electron transfer number and H2O2 yield were obtained by the following equations [57,58]: (5) n = 4 × I d I d + I r / N (6) H 2 O 2 % = 100 × 2 × I r / N I d + I r / N where N is the collection efficiency (0.424) of the Pt ring. To determine the active site density of ZDC catalyst toward the ORR, nitrite reduction stripping measurements were conducted by modifying a documented protocol which includes electrode cleaning, surface poisoning and stripping steps [59]. The catalyst loading on the RDE electrode was fixed at 0.2 mg cm−2. Prior to the stripping experiment, surface poisoning treatment using nitrite was first performed in 0.125 M NaNO2 solution, followed by a thorough rinsing in ultrapure water. The nitrite stripping experiment was then conducted in 0.5 M acetate buffer solution (pH = 5.2). The number of active sites was quantified by measuring the nitrite reduction stripping charge (Qstrip ) on Fe(II)-Nx motifs, assuming that the reductive stripping of one adsorbed NO per site would consume 5 electrons (nstrip = 5) [59]. Qstrip was determined by integrating the reduction signal corresponding to NO stripping signal. The mass site density (MSD) and areal site density (ASD) can then be calculated according to the following equations: (7) M S D m o l g - 1 = Q strip C g - 1 n strip F C mol - 1 (8) A S D s i t e nm - 2 = Q strip C g - 1 N A ( mol - 1 ) n strip F C mol - 1 E A S A ( nm 2 g - 1 ) 3 Results 3.1 Synthesis and characterization The ZDC materials were synthesized by pyrolyzing ZIF-67 particles that were prepared via the reaction between cobalt ions and 2-methylimidazole ligand in methanol solution [28]. The resultant ZDC materials were subjected to acid leaching to remove accessible cobalt particles. The synthetic procedure is illustrated in Fig. 1 . The as-prepared ZIF-67 particles all exhibit a unique rhombic dodecahedron shape with smoothly exposed surfaces. The average sizes of as-prepared ZIF-67 particles are varied in the range of 300 nm to 1.8 µm (Figure S1). After the pyrolysis treatment, the homogeneous particle morphology as well as the characteristic rhombic dodecahedron shape can be well maintained (Fig. 2 a-e). At the same time, shrinkage in the particle size and surface roughening can be identified, which would mainly stem from the anisotropic thermal contraction of the ZIF nanoparticle induced by continuously formed carbon layer [60]. To better probe the microstructure of the as-prepared ZDC materials, TEM images of ZDC were captured (Figure S2). Fig. 2f-g shows the representative TEM images of ZDC-5 (300 nm), the well-defined polyhedral shape and highly porous structure can be observed. The TEM images clearly reveal the presence of cobalt nanoparticles embedded in the carbon microstructure. The lattice fringes with a typical interplane distance of 0.205 nm can be seen in the HRTEM image of ZDC-5 (Fig. 2h), which agrees with the (111) planes of face-centered-cubic (fcc) cobalt [31]. The presence of carbon layers can also be confirmed by the selected area electron diffraction (the inset in Fig. 2h). It is worth noting that these carbon layers tend to exhibit high graphitic character, which is attributable to the catalytic influence of Co during the pyrolysis process. Therefore, these carbon-encapsulated cobalt nanoparticles are in principle inaccessible to reactants/electrolyte due to the wrapping of the carbon overlayer even after the acid leaching (Figure S3). To probe the distribution of various elements on the ZDCs, EDS elemental mapping analysis of ZDC-5 was carried out. As shown in Fig. 2i, C, N, Co and O are homogeneously distributed all over the selected ZDC particle. The Co nanoparticles can also be clearly identified. The XRD analysis was used to investigate the crystalline structure of the as-synthesized ZDCs in this work (Fig. 3 a). The diffraction patterns of ZDCs exhibit similar features regardless of their particle sizes. The peak at around 26.2° corresponds to the C(002) plane, while the peaks at 44.2° and 51.5° can be assigned to Co(111) and Co(200), respectively [61]. This suggests that cobalt in ZDCs mainly exists in the form of metallic cobalt with a fcc structure. Based on the Scherrer equation, the average crystallite sizes of cobalt in ZDCs are calculated to be ∼8 nm. Raman spectroscopy was employed to investigate the graphitization degree of ZDCs (Fig. 3b). Two characteristic peaks corresponding to the disorder-induced band (D band) and the graphite band (G band) are observed at 1350 and 1590 cm−1, respectively. The peak intensity ratio between these two bands (ID /IG ) is usually used as an indicator for the graphitization degree of carbon materials, i.e., the higher the ratio, the lower the graphitization degree [61]. The ID /IG ratio is determined to be ∼1.1, indicating comparable graphitization degree of ZDCs irrespective of their particle sizes. No additional peak can be identified in the Raman spectra, confirming the complete carbonization of ZIF-67 after the pyrolysis treatment. The nitrogen sorption measurements were also conducted to examine the textural structure of ZDCs. As shown in Fig. 3c and 3d, ZDCs have comparable porosity and textural structure regardless of their particle sizes. Although ZDC-5 exhibits the smallest BET surface area due to the highest residual Co content among ZDCs, it has a higher pore volume (0.43 cm3 g−1) than the others, mainly contributed by the abundant mesopores (Figure S4). The pore size distribution (PSD) curves indicated that the as-prepared ZDCs possess quite similar PSD features in the microporous and mesoporous regimes, whereas a more significant amount of pore volume with the pore size above 10 nm is observed on ZDC-5, indicating the presence of more abundant mesopores/macropores within ZDC-5 sample. These characteristic results demonstrate that the ZDCs synthesized in this work in principle have similar textural structure and porosity, which are in line with previous findings [42,48]. 3.2 Electrocatalytic ORR performance evaluation To evaluate the ORR performance of the as-prepared ZDCs, RRDE thin film technique was employed, and the measurements were carried out in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH electrolyte. The ORR polarization curves on various ZDC catalysts shown in Fig. 4 a reveal that ZDC with smaller particle size is more active toward the ORR, as indicated by the more positive half-wave potential and higher diffusion limiting current density. Specifically, ZDC-5 with the smallest particle size (300 nm) is identified as the best performing catalyst by exhibiting a half wave potential of 0.833 V. The diffusion limiting current density increases from 4.45 mA cm−2 on ZDC-1 (1.8 μm) to 5.23 mA cm−2 on ZDC-5 (300 nm). Considering that the ORR can proceed either following the four-electron pathway to produce water or following the two-electron pathway to produce hydrogen peroxide species, herein, we used the RRDE technique to probe the ORR pathway. The formation of hydrogen peroxide species (i.e., HO2 −in alkaline electrolyte) is monitored by recording the current collected by the Pt ring electrode. As shown in Fig. 4b, ZDCs exhibit small ring current densities (<0.165 mA cm−2) which decreases with the ZDC particle size. The formed HO2 − concentration is less than 13 mol% for all the investigated samples (Fig. 4c). The electron transfer numbers are also determined based on the slope of K-L plots at different RRDE rotation rates (Figure S5), which are close to 4 (Fig. 4c), implying that the ORR proceeds predominantly via the four-electron pathway on these ZDC samples. To better probe the intrinsic activity of ZDCs toward the ORR, the mass-transfer corrected kinetic current density at 0.85 V is determined according to the K-L equation (Supporting Information). In Fig. 4d, we observe a discernible dependency of the kinetic current density on the ZDC particle size. To be noted, compared to the widely adopted half wave potential or kinetic current density, mass activity, which is defined as the kinetic current normalized to the mass loading the active material, is proposed as a more fundamental figure of metric for evaluating the ORR performance [62]. In this context, the mass activity values for different ZDCs were determined as follows: 4.9, 5.8, 6.0, 6.2, and 7.8 A g−1, exhibiting a trend of increase corresponding to diminishing ZDC particle sizes. The ZDC with smaller particle size exhibits not only a higher kinetic current density but also a greater mass activity, while a similar trend also holds for the diffusion limiting current densities of ZDCs. The best performing ZDC-5 (300 nm) shows a kinetic current density of 1.56 mA cm−2 (7.8 A g−1) and a diffusion limiting current density of 5.23 mA cm−2, which are substantially higher than that of other ZDC samples. It is also documented that the ORR activity might show a dependence on the mass loading of the catalyst on RDE [62]. Herein, to clarify whether the observed ORR activity trend across various ZDCs retains at different catalyst loadings, we assessed the ORR activity at ZDC mass loadings of 150, 200 and 300 µg cm−2. As depicted in Figure S6, increasing the catalyst loading from 150 to 200 µg cm−2 resulted in a clear enhancement in the apparent kinetic current density for all the investigated samples. However, further increasing the catalyst loading to 300 µg cm−2 yielded only a marginal increment in the apparent kinetic current density. Notably, the mass activity of the most active ZDC-5 is more or less comparable when the mass loading is increased from 150 to 200 µg cm−2, i.e., 7.5 vs. 7.8 A g−1, while a substantially lower mass activity is observed when further increasing the mass loading to 300 µg cm−2 (5.7 A g−1), likely due to the increased transport losses within the thick catalyst layer [62]. Nonetheless, the ORR activity trend across different ZDC particle sizes remains consistent. These results again confirm the inherently higher activity of smaller ZDC particles toward the ORR in alkaline electrolyte. 4 Discussion The above results reveal a fascinating correlation between the ORR activity and the particles sizes of ZDC materials. Similar size-dependent ORR activity has also been observed in the previous work. For instance, Zou and colleagues demonstrated a significant increase in ORR activity in acidic electrolyte as the particle size of ZIF-67 derived carbon decreases, which can be attributed to enhanced mass and electro-transport properties [36]. Wu and coworkers examined the ORR activity of Fe-ZIF derived carbon particles of different sizes. They found that smaller particles exhibit higher kinetic current density toward the ORR in acidic electrolyte, possibly due to an increasing number of exposed active sites [42]. Cui et al. conducted a comprehensive study on the size effect of ZIF-67 derived carbons on the ORR performance. This involved the examination of a range of monodisperse ZDC particles with average sizes spanning from 180 nm to 3.2 µm. The study revealed a notable enhancement in ORR activity as the particle size reduced to 300 nm. However, diminishing the particle size further yielded only marginal improvements. This distinct size-dependent effect was attributed to the reduced diffusion length of both reactant and electrolyte molecules within the smaller ZDC particles, resulting in enhanced accessibility to active sites [45]. Despite these findings, unambiguously pinpointing the true active sites within ZDC materials and establishing a quantitative correlation between the structure and ORR activity remain a grand challenge. The EASA serves as a valuable metric for evaluating the exposed surface that participates in electrocatalytic reactions, which is frequently invoked to correlate with electrocatalytic activity. In this study, we quantified the EASA of various ZDCs by measuring the non-faradaic double layer capacitance through recording the CV curves at different scan rates (Figure S7). Reduction in ZDC particle size results in a modest increase in EASA. Specifically, the EASA of ZDC increases from 96.2 m2 g−1 for ZDC-1 (1.8 µm) to 115.5 m2 g−1 for ZDC-5 (300 nm), as summarized in Table S1. This indicates that the smaller ZDC particles exhibit a greater accessible surface area when interacting with liquid electrolyte. Although the electrochemically accessible surface is not necessarily catalytically active toward the ORR, an elevated EASA value often corresponds to a higher utilization of active sites. However, as observed in this work, the enhancement in EASA (1.2 times) is not directly proportional to the enhancement in ORR activity (1.6 times). This disparity largely stems from the uncertainty in the active site density. A comprehensive diagnosis and quantification of active species within these ZDC catalysts thus becomes essential. In the context of metal nitrogen co-doped carbon based NMPCs, previous studies have proposed various doped nitrogen species or metal-nitrogen coordination structures (M−Nx) as the potential active component toward the ORR [2,13,23,63–65], as illustrated in Fig. 5 a. XPS is commonly employed to distinguish and quantify the various nitrogen functionalities. In this study, XPS measurements were conducted on ZDC materials (Figure S8), and the resulting high resolution XPS signals of C 1 s, N 1 s and Co 2p reveal the presence of various nitrogen functionalities, including pyridinic N (398.5 eV), Co-Nx (399.3 eV), pyrrolic N (400.1 eV), graphitic N (401.1 eV) and oxidized N (402.1 eV). The detailed atomic ratios of these N functionalities are summarized in Fig. 5b. It can be observed that the most prominent N species is pyridinic N regardless of the particle size, which is consistent with the previous report [36]. However, elucidating a clear correlation between the ORR activity and the nitrogen functionalities presents a significant challenge, as depicted in Fig. 5b. Therefore, it is imperative to revisit the viability of quantifying the nitrogen functionalities pertinent to ORR activity using XPS technique. The ZDC particles used in this study had an average particle size ranging from 1.8 µm to 300 nm, which is far beyond the detection depth of XPS technique (<10 nm) [66]. Hence, XPS can only probe the nitrogen functionalities on the outermost layer of ZDC particles. To investigate whether the surface and interior of ZDC particles have similar composition and nitrogen functionalities, ZDC particles are fragmented by the ball-milling. Figure S9 confirms that the ZDC particles became smaller and turn into irregularly shaped fragments. An initial observation reveals that the fragmented ZDC-1 particles demonstrate EASA value quite akin to that of the pristine counterpart (98.5 vs. 96.2 m2 g−1), indicating that the pores situated within the ZDC particles remain accessible to the aqueous electrolyte. This underscores the significance of the interior composition of ZDC particles in influencing the ORR performance. Fig. 5c compares the N 1s signal of ZDC-1 before and after the ball-milling. The semi-quantitative analysis confirms that the distributions and types of nitrogen functionalities of the resulting fragments change significantly (Fig. 5d). Furthermore, the atomic N/C ratio (0.02) and the Co/C ratio (0.009) of ball-milled ZDC-1 exhibit significant deviations from those of pristine ZDC-1 (0.04, 0.005), providing further substantiation that the compositions of ZIF-derived carbon (ZDC) particles exhibit heterogeneity from surface to bulk. This outcome partially elucidates the challenges encountered in establishing a direct correlation between the ORR activity of ZDCs and the nitrogen functionalities probed via the surface-sensitive XPS. To gain a comprehensive understanding of the intricate relationships between nitrogen functionalities and the ORR performance, substantial efforts are required to accurately identify and quantify these functionalities. This task may necessitate the use of bulk-sensitive techniques, such as soft X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) [67–69]. For instance, Deng et al. characterized the chemical structure of FeN4/graphene composite using XAS, and based on the N K-edge signals they revealed that the amount of pyridinic N species had decreased after immobilizing the iron phthalocyanine precursor onto graphene nanosheets [69]. In addition to XAS, electron energy loss spectroscopy [70] and nuclear magnetic resonance [71] are also regarded as bulk sensitive techniques, which can be employed to characterize the chemical state of nitrogen-bearing functionalities. Moreover, it is also possible to identify and quantify nitrogen functionalities on nanocarbon materials using temperature programmed desorption-mass spectrometry (TPD-MS) [67,72–74]. As showcased in the benchmark of Schlögl et al., HCN, NH3 and NO and N2 desorption from the surface nitrogen doped CNTs with increasing temperature can be observed, from which the nitrogen functionalities such as pyridine, pyrrol, pyridine oxide, and lactam and be identified and quantified, despite that the peak deconvolution in this process remains a challenging task [72]. Among various nitrogen functionalities, metal nitrogen coordination structure (M−Nx) is recognized as the most active moiety toward the ORR [30,31,36], and is expected to play a critical role in reducing the ORR overpotential [30]. To this end, herein we have undertaken an effort to quantify the site density (SD) of Co-Nx on ZDCs using an innovative in situ electrochemical nitrite adsorption/stripping method, as pioneered by Kucernak’s group [59]. This emerging technique is grounded in the specific affinity between M−Nx sites and nitrite ions, resulting in the generation of adsorbed NO at M−Nx sites. The charge associated with the reductive stripping of adsorbed NO serves as a quantitative measure for determining the abundance of M−Nx sites on the surface of ZDC catalysts (Figure S10). As shown in Fig. 6 a, a pronounced reduction signal can be observed on the stripping voltammetry curve of ZDC-5. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first attempt to probe the SD of Co-Nx within NPMCs. The corresponding SD values are thus determined to be 17.7, 15.5, 14.9, 14.5 and 9.6 µmol g−1 as the size of ZDC particles increase from 300 nm to 1.8 µm (Table S1). This phenomenon suggests that ZDC particles with smaller dimensions encompass a more plentiful supply of accessible active sites. This distinct size-related behavior of SD might be attributed to two principal factors. Firstly, larger ZDC particles may potentially encounter more notable temperature gradients within their structures, potentially impacting the initial nucleation process and subsequent growth kinetics. Secondly, smaller ZDC particles, like ZDC-5, exhibit a greater abundance of mesopores/macropores, which could lead to distinct diffusion patterns for metal atoms towards pre-existing nuclei. To be noted, the acid leaching treatment plays a significant role in influencing the SD values. Intriguingly, it is observed that subjecting the catalyst to a 2-hour acid leaching at 80 °C appears sufficient for the removal of accessible cobalt nanoparticles, as evidenced by the increment in SD from 7.9 to 9.0 µmol g−1. However, extending the duration of the acid leaching process results in only a marginal enhancement (Figure S11), potentially attributed to the potential encapsulation of the nanoparticles by the carbon overlayer. Notably, the quantification of SD emerges as a viable approach for assessing the efficacy of acid leaching, a widely embraced technique for the preparation of NPMCs. It is also noteworthy that the fragmented ZDC-1 displays a comparable SD value compared to the pristine counterpart. This reinforces the idea that the active sites within the pores of ZDC particles remain accessible to the electrolyte and can still be probed using the nitrite adsorption/stripping method. It is noteworthy that both the diffusion limiting current and kinetic current densities of ZDCs at 0.85 V exhibit a substantial increase with the SD value. The augmented presence of Co-Nx sites in smaller-sized ZDCs accounts for the positive relationship between the number of active sites and the ORR activity of ZDCs. The non-linear dependence behavior indicates that, in addition to offering a large abundance of active sites, small-sized ZDCs may also fulfill some other beneficial role. The present study evaluates the ORR activity of ZDCs using the thin-film RDE technique, for which the K-L equation was employed as the benchmark approach to correcting for mass transport effects. However, it is important to note that the K-L equation corrects for the mass transfer of dissolved O2 from the bulk electrolyte to the electrode surface, without taking the internal diffusion of reactants within the catalyst layer into account. In other words, the deduced kinetic current values are determined by both the intrinsic ORR kinetics and the mass transfer rate within the pores of catalyst layer. As such, the shorter internal diffusion length within the pores of smaller ZDC particles is expected to promote the accessibility of active sites within the deep pores of the catalyst [45]. The distinct relationship between the kinetic current density and the SD value can be attributed to the combined impact of increased abundance and enhanced accessibility of active sites within the smaller-sized ZDC particles. The diffusion limiting current density (J L) is another crucial activity metric obtained from the RDE technique. It is determined by various factors such as the electrolyte properties, RDE dimension, and rotation rate, and is theoretically expected to attain a fixed value irrespective of the electrocatalysts employed. However, the practical J L values are generally lower than the theoretical value and vary between different catalysts, particularly for NPMCs due to their limited number and poorly defined distribution of active sites [75]. The deviation is most likely originated from the non-ideal hydrodynamic behavior of the catalyst-coated RDE, which compromises the assumption of the K-L equation. It is documented that the J L is influenced by the roughness factor of the catalyst-coated RDEs as well as the mass transfer within the catalyst layer [76]. In the present study, the high J L also benefits from both the high number of active sites, i.e., SD, and the facilitated internal diffusion within the small-sized ZDC particles. Moreover, as depicted in Fig. 4b and 4c, the smaller ZDC particles demonstrate reduced selectivity towards hydrogen peroxide species. It is well documented that the ORR mechanism involves two distinct pathways: the direct 4-electron pathway leading to water formation and the 2-electron peroxide pathway. In the latter, O2 undergoes initial reduction to peroxide species. These species can either desorb from active sites to generate the 2-electron product (HO2 –) or proceed with further reduction to produce water (indirect 4-electron pathway). In the context of the present study, the diminished selectivity towards hydrogen peroxide in smaller ZDCs implies that the augmented SD in these smaller particles likely enhances their capacity to adsorb hydrogen peroxide species, facilitating their subsequent reduction to water. Attempt has been also made to determine the areal SD of ZDCs by normalizing the number of Co-Nx sites to the EASA (Table S1). It turns out that the areal SD is approximately 0.059 and 0.092 site nm−2 at ZDC-1 and ZDC-5, respectively. The small areal SD values of ZDCs reflect their relatively low active SD relative to Pt-based ORR catalysts. The reason for the low SD of ZDC materials can be traced to the fact that during pyrolysis, the majority of Co in the ZIF precursor contributes to the formation of Co nanoparticles rather than Co-Nx active sites, as verified by the Co K-edge EXAFS and Morlet wavelet transform of ZDC-1 (Figure S12). This phenomenon can be attributed to tendency of Co species to undergo carbonthermal reduction at high temperature pyrolysis, which leads to the formation metallic Co particles. Therefore, there is a need to decouple the carbonization and formation of Co-Nx sites to increase the SD of these ZDCs. Remarkably, ZDC-1 exhibits quite similar areal SD before and after the ball-milling (0.059 vs. 0.062), indicating that the areal SD is an intrinsic structural parameter fixed after synthesis. These findings indicate that, compared to the type or content of nitrogen functionalities, the SD value may serve as a more appropriate metric for correlating with the ORR activity of NPMCs in alkaline electrolyte. The SD value holds the potential to be utilized as a quantitative activity descriptor for NMPCs, subject to further experimental investigations and computational modeling studies. 5 Conclusions In summary, we successfully synthesized a series of well-defined rhombic dodecahedron-shaped ZDC particles with average sizes ranging from 1.8 µm to 300 nm. A clear size-dependent trend in the electrocatalytic activity of ZDC particles during the ORR in alkaline electrolyte has been identified, i.e., the ORR activity increases substantially as the ZDC particle size decreases. The highest activity is obtained on the carbon particles derived from the smallest ZIF-67 precursor (300 nm), which delivers a kinetic current density of 1.56 mA cm−2 at 0.85 V and a half wave potential up to 0.833 V. To unravel the unique size-dependent ORR activity of ZDCs, attempts were made to quantify the type and contents of various nitrogen functionalities and more importantly the density of active sites (Co-Nx) of ZDCs. Our results reveal that there is no clear correlation between the ORR activity and the type or content of surface nitrogen functionalities probe by XPS. However, we found that the ORR activity exhibits a distinct dependence on the SD of ZDCs. This phenomenon can be attributed to a synergistic effect of greater abundance and higher accessibility of active sites on smaller-sized ZDC particles. The present work not only provides a facile way to construct high-performance NPMC toward the ORR in alkaline electrolyte, but also emphasizes the importance of proper size/porosity engineering to increase the utilization/accessibility of the active sites within the pores of catalysts, and most importantly, offers a new perspective in the development of carbon-based nanostructured catalysts for the ORR or other electrocatalytic reactions. coredata.dc:description: ZIF-derived carbons (ZDCs) represent a novel category of non-precious metal catalysts (NPMCs) for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR). Nevertheless, establishing the correlation between their structure and performance is challenging due to their diverse structural properties and ill-defined active site moieties. Here we investigate the effect of ZIF-67 derived carbon’s particle size and corresponding distribution of assorted nitrogen functionalities on the ORR. Our findings reveal a substantial increase in ORR activity with decreasing ZDC particle size, while the exact influence of nitrogen functionalities remains uncertain. Most importantly, the present work unveils a correlation between the ORR activity and the site density (SD) of Co-Nx within the ZDC materials, which can be attributed to the concurrently increasing SD and accessibility of Co-Nx on the ZDC particles with small sizes. The present work provides novel insights into the optimization of ZDCs as high-performance NPMCs for ORR in alkaline electrolytes.
coredata.dc:title: Toward quantification of active site density and size-dependent ORR activity of ZIF-derived carbons in alkaline electrolyte
